answerText: jump [or branch][10] This name is given to the act of affecting the order in which instructions are executed. The jump is the most basic method of doing this task, though statements like "if" and "while" are more common in high-level languages.
heading: ACF Regionals 2014 |2014 | Dorman-Carleton-LASA B | 19 | Science | Computer Science | College
subject: Science
question: Question:  [10] Name these instructions that cause a computer to transfer execution to a different sequence of instructions. Namesake "predictors" like saturating counters attempt to determine where control will be transferred by one of these instructions.
